column44: Campus initiative to include in courses
column71: Adopting open textbooks (fairly straightforward), developing ancillary materials to accompany an open text (a lot of work and contributions in kind from our experienced course development team and SMEs).  One thing to note is that not everyone in the process was aware of what the license agreements of open textbooks allowed (ie reuse open textbook content directly in course) - so there was come confusion within our internal teams.  Reviewing entire courses (as possible straight across adoption).  Both open courses I reviewed contained materials that were inappropriate for our specific institutional context. One example was a sustainability course that contained video lectures - these were very specific to the US context, and also very specific to the classroom spaces (ie reference to US elections, specific reference to homework and assignments). In both cases it would have been easier to build something from scratch than to adapt the "open" resource (depending on how you design open). The resources were not designed for open access and open design principles were not used.
column121: For the online context I don't think there is any evidence about most of the above statements. My question is "how do we know" without the research? The small amount of research that I have seen presented is related to F2F teaching.

column71: Using OERs is encouraged and supported at my institution.  Many SMEs are unaware of open resources or the copyright issues with resources they find, so there is some training involved.  One complication I've found is when an OER course is modified and may no longer fit the needs of the learning activity in my course.  In any case, I promote these resources to my SMEs, and they can be rich resources to support student engagement.
column121: Allows for self-directed learning, as students can explore further topics using the OER (e.g. open course).
column123: It takes a lot of time to find resources that are as high quality as a polished Pearson text for example.  It's often easier to go with the publishers, as they have already selected images, articles, websites, videos, quizzes. etc. that go with your topic.
column136: Using an OER in a course broaden's everyone's educational experience - from the students, SMEs, IDs, and other members of the development team (media, IP, editing).
column137: It takes time and money to gain copyright permission for licensed materials.  In addition, as an ID, we have to make tentative plans for deleting a resource is no permission is granted.  With OERs we can more likely modify and adapt the materials, as well as download to our institutional server.
column138: The use of OERs is supported and encouraged in institutional practices and policies.
column140: It would be helpful to have more resources dedicated to looking for quality OERs.  There is some help from librarians, the media team, and copyright officers, but most of the time it is up to the ID.  There are several search engines for OERs, but there are too many low-quality resources to sift through.  A better image/text/video bank with several filters would be helpful.
column141: SME buy-in, low quality OERs, content of OERs changing, time to search for resources.
column142: I've seen it and I know what it means
column144: Open access to all students in all places.
column145: Yes, they are publicly viewable but I don’t have a license on them that allows them to be revised and reused.
column147: I've mainly shared my presentations given at conferences, but often upload as pdf.  This requires the student/viewer to be more critical of slides they want to copy and use for their own purposes.  I plan to upload many more teaching materials.  Some will be open license, depending on the requirements and benefits of viewers modifying the materials.
column148: Many of our course activities and resources I would like to put online, but they are the property of the institution.  OERs are supported, but not putting our courses online - yet!

column71: My institution is open to the use of Open Textbooks but the opportunity hasn't presented itself. We are encouraged to use OERs as resources within courses.
column142: I've seen it and I know what it means
column144: Openness refers to increased access to education - removing barriers of time, space, entry requirements, fees, etc.
column145: No, but I share them with colleagues or others when asked.
column147: I no longer teach full time so am not as involved in creating materials. If I were, I would make them available.

column44: BC Campus staff, Ron McGivern at TRU, emails on listserves
column70: to modify and adapt for new courses, for research purposes (what works)
column71: support from my director to use them, quite a few interested faculty but not enough, uptake growing as more usuable and accessible OER available, problems with source materials at times...not easy to modify , faculty sometimes find it easier to use publisher materials and like convenience of the add ons, facultry not aware of quality of current peer reviewed OER, I know courses can be built completely using OER...but not sure savings are being passed on to students
column121: OER makes resources more available to disadvantaged students, reduces their costs...can be translated, modified, contextualized and shared widely...a social justice initiative
column123: open for feedback and review so wider input from experts, can be constantly improved based on feedback, can be modified to suit unique needs eg made for Aboriginal context
column136: I take free courses  I use materials shared by others eg UBC and KUMU wikis, WikiEducator, OERu etc  I include more free multimedia in courses
column137: embed directly in online courses  changed modalities easily  put lots of images and multimedia  asked for feedback to incorporate changes/improvements immediately  shared with other faculty during design so they see course as it is being developed  shared objects from course with others for their use  use only parts of materials ..mix and match to suit needs  update easily, add current examples as needed   vary images as needed to suit different audiences
column138: faculty (including IDs) encouraged to use OER but not mandated to do so  support at Open Learning for making some OER ourselves  TRU library now has info on website about using OER  KUMU wiki established to show how to make and use OER  Director of Innovation actively promotes OER as part of job...brought in experts eg Alan Levine, organizes workshops, supports staff  TRU founding partner of OERu so leading the way in championing OER use  Several faculty involved in OER promotion...go to Open Ed conferences etc  Moving towards open source LMS..away from any propietary tools
column141: source materials not easy to work with, materials not available for some areas, materials too American (or British etc)...not enough Canadian content, no supplementary materials eg quizzes, PPTs, materials hard to find, takes time to review something new...not sure if high quality since I am not an expert in subject, takes time and money to modify OER to suit needs
column142: I've seen it and I know what it means
column145: Yes, they are publicly viewable and I put a license on them that allows them to be revised and reused.
column147: think it's beneficial to share with others for them to use as they wish...and I can benefit from others too
column148: some materials are owned by my employer and not mine to share as I wish
column159: at a hotel, also while travelling via wifi

column71: I have found Subject Matter Experts are open to using OER materials when they are presented with them. Many SME's are not familiar with OER so part of our job is to educate them about all aspects.  Some SME's have written open text books. This process is very time consuming.  I think adopting OER's has not affected learning, but a study to confirm such thoughts would be interesting.
column121: We have no data that would allow to reliably answer any of these questions.
column123: Text books are very well done. They are just expensive. OER are very well done, however they lack the financial backing at this point to be as broadly based as some commercially available learning material.
column138: TRU OL is supportive of using OER. There is nothing I know that inhibits the use, development, etc. of OER.
column141: It is a general lack of knowledge on the part of SME's that is one barrier. However another is having locally based content when a  resource is available.
column142: I've seen it and I know what it means

column121: I taught one course without a textbook (journal articles only). The same course was offered simultaneously with a $300 textbook. The students appreciated my effort to stay away from the book.
column123: Not all OERs have ancillary resources yet (e.g. tests, quizzes, assignments, videos, etc.). If they did, I would say that OERs are superior because they set students up for success and allow the instructor to adapt the resource to his/her needs.
column138: Not aware of any policies. We are encouraged to use OERs.
column140: ...If we were encouraged to deposit our materials on a TRU server - for everyone to see and access: When a new person is hired (usually sessionals)  they have last minute scrambles to get resources together. What if instructors deposited their teaching resources in a central space where new people can access them?
column142: I've seen it and I know what it means
column145: No, but I share them with colleagues or others when asked.
column147: Maybe I don't have the self-confidence yet to share my resources publicly. I don't know how/where to do that yet.
